name: Similar Pairs
description:
We call two numbers 
    x
 and 
    y
 similar if they have the same parity
(the same remainder when divided by 
    2
), or if 
    |x-y|=1
. For
example, in each of the pairs 
    (2, 6)
, 
    (4, 3)
, 
    (11, 7)
, the
numbers are similar to each other, and in the pairs 
    (1, 4)
, 
    (3,
    12)
, they are not. You are given an array 
    a
 of 
    n
 (
    n
 is
even) positive integers. Check if there is such a partition of the array into
pairs that each element of the array belongs to exactly one pair and the
numbers in each pair are similar to each other. For example, for the array

    a = [11, 14, 16, 12]
, there is a partition into pairs 
    (11, 12)
 and

    (14, 16)
. The numbers in the first pair are similar because they differ
by one, and in the second pair because they are both even. Input The first
line contains a single integer 
    t
 (
    1 
    ≤ t 
    ≤ 1000
) — the
number of test cases. Then 
    t
 test cases follow. Each test case consists
of two lines. The first line contains an even positive integer 
    n
 (
    2
    
    ≤ n 
    ≤ 50
) — length of array 
    a
. The second line contains

    n
 positive integers 
    a_1, a_2, 
    …, a_n
 (
    1 
    ≤ a_i 
    ≤
    100
). Output For each test case print: YES if the such a partition exists,
NO otherwise. The letters in the words YES and NO can be displayed in any
case. Example Input 7 4 11 14 16 12 2 1 8 4 1 1 1 1 4 1 2 5 6 2 12 13 6 1 6 3
10 5 8 6 1 12 3 10 5 8 Output YES NO YES YES YES YES NO Note The first test
case was explained in the statement. In the second test case, the two given
numbers are not similar. In the third test case, any partition is suitable.
